GRANTEE: THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, DAVIS

Department of Land, Air and Water Resources, and

Department of Geology

Davis, California 95616

GRANT: DE-FG03-96ER14629

TITLE: The Energetics of Reactions at Mineral Surfaces and Their Coupling to Disequilibria

PERSONS IN CHARGE: William H. Casey (916-752-3211; Fax 916-752-1562; E-mail whcasey@ucdavis.edu) and Brian L. Phillips (Department of Chemical Engineering and Material Sciences; 916-752-4396; Fax 916-752-9554; E-mail blphillips@ucdavis.edu)

Objectives: We are establishing a reactivity scale for reactions at oxide mineral surfaces by determining rate coefficients for key elementary reactions in model dissolved complexes. The 17O-NMR method is used to determine the rates of water exchange between the inner-coordination-sphere of Al(III)-ligand-H2O complexes and the bulk solvent as a measure of the fundamental reactivity of the inner-sphere metal-oxygen bonds. The broad features of this reactivity scale are established (Phillips et al., 1997a; Phillips et al., 1997b) and we are now examining the Al13(O4)OH24(H 2O)127+(aq) multimer, which has key features in common with truncated monomolecular steps on aluminum (hydr)oxide mineral surfaces. Ab-initio molecular-orbital calculations are also underway via collaboration with Prof. J. Tossell at the University of Maryland to establish a relation between bond lengths, bond strengths, and values in these, and other, complexes (Figure 1).

Results:

General Model

We have established that rate coefficients describing metal detachment from a mineral surface scale like rates of water exchange between bulk solvent and the inner-coordination sphere of certain metal-ligand complexes (e.g., Casey and Westrich, 1992; Ludwig et al., 1995). The essential idea is that stable ligands in the inner-coordination sphere of Al(III) modify the reactivity of other bonds to oxygens that are also in the inner-coordination sphere. These elementary reaction rate coefficients can, by hypothesis, be quantitatively used to predict rate coefficients for the surface reactions (see Ludwig et al., 1995; 1996; Casey and Ludwig, 1996) if there is structural similarity between the surface and dissolved complexes. Because the increase in reactivity is usually accompanied by an increase in bond lengths, we are coupling these rate measurements to molecular-orbital calculations to extend the rate data (Figure 1).

Figure 1: The exchange of fluoride ions for hydration waters in dissolved Al(III) complexes labilizes the remaining waters of hydration. This ligand-directed labilization is probably accompanied by a bond lengthening, indicating that a Linear-Free-Energy correlation can be established relating reactivity to bond lengths and bond strengths in stable complexes. Bond lengths are in Angstrom units.

Rates in Aluminum-Fluoride, -Oxalate and -Malonato Complexes

At 298 K, the rate coefficient for water exchange [k298] in Al(H2O)63+(aq) is 2.7(±1.2) s-1 (Phillips et al., 1997). Upon replacement of a single water of hydration with fluoride to form the AlF(H2O)52+(aq) complex, the rate coefficient increases to »102 s-1. Upon adding a second fluoride ion, the rate coefficient increases to »20000 s-1. A similar result is found for aluminum oxalate complexes, although the effect is not so dramatic. Replacement of waters of hydration in Al(H2O)63+(aq) to form the bidentate monooxalato complex [i.e., Al(C2O4)(H2O) 4+(aq)] causes k298 to increase to »102 s-1. Our current work on methylmalonato-complexes indicates that important complexities can arise. The k298 values were predicted (Figure 2) to scale with the equilibrium constant and with the size of the ring formed by the chelate and the Al(III) metal; in other words, oxalato- complexes would be more reactive than malonato complexes of similar structure. To our surprise, we find that k298»1100 s-1 for the bidentate mono-methylmalonato complex and k298»10000 s-1 for the bis-bidentate complex, which is much more reactive than anticipated.

Predicting Rates Using a Linear-Free-Energy Relation

In Figure 2 we compare the rate coefficient for exchange of water in the complexes with the overall equilibrium constant. Also plotted for comparison are the rate coefficients predicted for water exchange between the bulk solution and the inner-coordination sphere of Al(III)-phthalate and Al(III) methylmalonate complexes. Rate coefficients are predicted for both the mono- and bis-bidentate complexes. These are carboxylate complexes that mimic the carboxylate functionalities present in natural organic matter.

These rate coefficients are determined at the most fundamental level of real molecular motions and are extrapolatable to a wide range of processes if the rate-controlling step in these reactions is dissociation of a metal-oxygen bond. We are now exploring exchange on the Al13(O4)OH24(H 2O)127+(aq) multimer, which has twelve h1-OH2 sites, two sets of twelve µ2-OH groups and four µ4-oxo groups. This complex was chosen because of its structural similarity to sites exposed by truncation of the [010] surface of g-Al2O3(s) or the [001] surface of Bayerite. The areal charge density on the multimer is »10  µmoles/m2, which compares well with the 1-9 µmoles/m2 charge densities on minerals such as bayerite at pH values<PZNPC. These Al13(O4)OH24(H 2O)127+(aq) molecules in fact link together with over hours to form colloids initially with a psuedo-spinel structure [g-Al2O3·H2O] and ultimately with the bayerite [ß-Al(OH)3] structure.

Figure 2: Rate coefficients for the exchange of water molecules between the inner-coordination sphere of Al(III)-ligand-H2O complexes at 298 K versus the equilibrium constant for the overall equilibrium. The filled symbols (C) are measured values and the unfilled squares ( ) are predictions for other Al(III)-ligand complexes. Two rate coefficients are predicted for these complexes because both mono- and bis- complexes form in aqueous solution.

References: 1Casey, W. H. and Ludwig, Chr. (1996) The mechanism of dissolution of oxide minerals. Nature 381, 506-509. 2Casey, W. H. and Ludwig, Chr. (1995) Silicate mineral dissolution as a ligand-exchange reaction. ch. 3 in : Weathering Kinetics of Silicate Minerals (eds. S. Brantley and A. Nature 375, 44-47. 5Ludwig, Chr., Devidal, J.-L., and Casey, W. H. (1996) The effect of different functional groups on the ligand-promoted dissolution of NiO(s) and other oxide minerals. Geochim. GRANTEE: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, DAVIS

Thermochemistry Facility

Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Sciences

Davis, California 95616-8779

GRANT: DE-FG03-97ER14749

TITLE: Thermodynamics of Minerals Stable Near the Earth's Surface

PERSON IN CHARGE: Alexandra Navrotsky (916-752-3292; Fax 916-752-9307; E-mail anavrotsky@ucdavis.edu)

Objectives: The goals of the project are to increase both the data base and the fundamental understanding of the thermodynamics of volatile-bearing mineral phases (amphiboles, micas, clays, zeolites, carbonates) important to surficial, sedimentary, and shallow crustal processes.

Project Description: Using high temperature solution calorimetry, this research determines the enthalpies of formation of hydrous minerals and carbonates. Systematics in energetics of ionic substitutions are sought in order to predict the thermodynamics of complex multicomponent minerals. Mixing properties of mica, amphibole, clay, zeolite, and carbonate solid solutions are also studied. The calorimetry facility has moved from Princeton to the University of California at Davis.

Results: Carbonates: Study of a largely disordered series of synthetic ankerites (Mg,Fe)Ca(CO3)2 and of more ordered natural samples confirm significant differences in enthalpy between the two groups of materials. These are consistent with an enthalpy of disordering of MgCa(CO3)2 of 20-25 kJ/mol and an enthalpy of disordering of FeCa(CO3)2 of about 10 kJ/mol. The rather large enthalpy of disordering of dolomite is supported both by the systematics of solid solution energetics derived by Davies and Navrotsky (1982) and by a calorimetric study of a metastable apparently totally disordered CaMg(CO3)2 sample made from aqueous solution. The latter sample is energetically less stable than a mixture of huntite CaMg3(CO3)4 and Ca-rich dolomite to which it decomposes on heating. The system SrCO3-CaCO3 has been studied by calorimetry.

Zeolites: Work on the Ca-zeolites (laumontite, leonhardite, yugawaralite, wairakite) and their ion-exchanged forms has been published. The energetics of ion exchange and hydration in other zeolites is under investigation. The energetics of the Si = Al + Na substitution is similar in faujasites and aluminosilicate glasses. The energetics of hydration of chabazites is being studied. Their heats of formation, for anhydrous frameworks, appear similar to those of glasses of similar composition.

Clays: Drop solution calorimetry in molten lead borate at 702 ºC allowed us to redetermine the heat of formation of kaolinite and dickite in agreement with Barany and Kelley (1961). The energetics of the polytypism of the kaolin minerals has been extended to several differently crystallized kaolinites and the minerals nacrite and halloysite.

Enthalpy of formation in the illite/smectite system has been investigated for the first time. The samples studied, all natural, are mostly reference clays from the Clay Minerals Society. They give a good coverage of the sedimentary sequences with different stages of mixed layer compounds. However the various levels of impurities, always found in natural samples, increase the uncertainty. To go further, selected compositional series have been prepared. The enthalpy of formation at room temperature and the heat capacity between 50 and 250ºC have been measured in a cation exchanged smectite series between sodium and potassium. Recrystallization of smectite under hydrothermal conditions permitted the synthesis of a mixed layer clay at constant chemistry. This type of synthesis should allow better insight into diagenesis by applying the thermochemical measurements now in progress.

The sensitivity of drop solution calorimetry to the water adsorbed led us to develop appropriate experimental methods. Additional experiments on water-clay energetics are planned.

GRANTEE: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, DAVIS

Department of Chemistry and

Department of Land, Air and Water Resources

Davis, CA 95616

GRANT: DE-FG03-92ER14307

TITLE: Electrochemical Measurement of Thermodynamics Properties of Minerals and the Processes of Reconstruction at Mineral Surfaces

PERSONS IN CHARGE: Peter A. Rock (916-754-8918; Fax 916-754-9057; E-mail rock@lsdo.ucdavis.edu) and William H. Casey (916-752-3211; Fax 916-752-1552; E-mail whcasey@ucdavis.edu)

Objectives: We are: (1) measuring thermodynamic properties for some carbonate solid-solution minerals that are important in soils and aquifers; (2) devising new theoretical approaches to the calculation of the energetics of calcite-structure metal carbonates in pure and binary phases; (3) and, using AFM to explore the processes of reconstruction at mineral surfaces.

Project Description: Our new method is an electrochemical double cell without liquid junction. Such a cell for cadmium-carbonate minerals is (Rock et al., 1994, Geochim. Cosmochim. Acta 58, 4281-4291):

Cd(Hg,2-phase)|CdCO3(s)|CaCO 3(s)

|CaC12(aq)|Hg2 C12(s)|Hg(1)

Hg(1)|Hg2C12(s)|CaC1 2(aq),CdC12(aq)

|CdxCa1-xCO 3(s)|CdCO3(s)|Cd (Hg,2-phase)

yielding a net cell reaction of:

(CaCO3)calcite+(1-x) CdC12(aq) =

(CaxCd1-xCO 3)Cd-calcite+(1-x)CaC12 (aq)

Values of DƒGo for the solid solution relative to the end members are obtained from the cell voltage and known activities of the electrolytes. With these DƒGo values, we estimate excess Gibbs energies of mixing (DGex) and the partitioning of metals into the solid solutions at equilibrium. The DGex values are compared with enthalpies of mixing (DHmix) determined via high-temperature, drop-solution calorimetry.

Results: Electrochemical studies of mixing in the CaCO3­CdCO3, CaCO3-SrCO3 CaCO3-MnCO3, and CaCO3-MgCO3 binary systems are complete and the results prove the methods suitability. Novel electrochemical cells also were constructed for the determination of DƒGo of hydrocerrusite and hydrozincite (submitted to American Mineral. August 1997). We have also applied our electrochemical method to determine DƒGo values at 25°C, 1 bar for Zn, Pb, Hg and Cd oxalates (U. Kubacky-Beard, et. al., Geochim. Cosmochim. Acta 60:1283-89 (1996)).

The electrochemical method provides a means of estimating thermodynamic properties at the low temperatures that are characteristic of most soils and aquifers. At these conditions, acid-solution calorimetry is not sufficiently accurate for determining enthalpies of reaction, because CO2 degasses slowly from an aqueous solution. Solubility experiments are likewise difficult because secondary minerals typically precipitate in a dissolution experiment, thereby complicating interpretation of the data. Metastable equilibrium is much easier to achieve with the electrochemical cells that we employ because the voltage measurements do not dramatically perturb the system, unlike dissolution experiments where a significant fraction of the solid must be dissolved to receive information. Thermodynamic data are also derived from the electrochemical cell data directly, without a complicated model for solute speciation. Equilibrium in the cell can be demonstrated through: (i) Nernstian response of the potential to changes in solute activities; (ii) the absence of hysterisis in voltage-current plots for the cell; and (iii) the rapid and reversible response of the cell voltage to temperature cycling. The method is also demonstrably accurate, our estimated value of DƒGo for otavite (CdCO3) and calcite (CaCO3) are within 2kJ•mol-1 of the NBS values reported in Wagman et al., 1982 (J. Phys. Chem. Ref. Data 11 [Supl. 2] 1-392.

A theoretical method for calculating lattice energies of calcite-structure metal carbonates has been devised. By separating the lattice energy (DU) into polarization, electrostatic, and replusive components, the calculation of DU is done in a step-wise fashion, whereby each of the three components of DU is first found as a function of the partial charge on oxygen (Qoxy) in each of the solid metal carbonates under investigation. The polarization component of DU is found through a two-step process. First, the oxygen polarizabilities in the solid metal carbonates are computed via the Lorentz Local Field Method, which requires crystal refractive indices as input. Next, a self-consistent approach is employed to determine the dipole moment on oxygen while it resides in the carbonate mineral. With this information at hand, the polarization contribution to DU can be found as a function of Qoxy.

The determination of the electrostatic component of DU is done by means of a coulombic point charge approach which takes into account the change in the carbonate ion charge distribution as it transfers to the crystal phase from the gas phase. The charge distribution of CO32-(g) is found via molecular-orbital calculations with Gaussian `94. Evaluation of the repulsive segment of DU is accomplished by means of the Slater repulsive potential, which is also known as the Inverse Power Law.  By imposing an equilibrium condition on DU with respect to interionic separation distance, the value of the repulsive energy in each metal carbonate is obtained as a function of Qoxy.

With )U calculated as a function of Qoxy, Gaussian `94 is used for the determination of Qoxy in each carbonate mineral in order to assign a numerical value to DU. After calculating DU for a variety of calcite-structure metal carbonates, the approach is extended to solid solutions of the same crystal structure type. Excess Gibbs energy values are then predicted for several solid solutions by coupling the lattice energy calculation method of this work to subregular solution models.

Manuscripts based on our theoretical work on calcite-structure metal carbonates have been submitted to the Journal of Physics and Chemistry of Solids. These papers will be followed by a manuscript on the energetics of formation of metal carbonate solid solutions (CaxM1-xCO3 where M is Cd, Mn, Fe or Mg).

We are also collaborating with Pat Brady (Sandia) on the experimental determination of the Gibbs energy change for the reactions:

CaMg(CO3)2(s) [Brady]XCaMg(CO3)2(s)[natural]

Where "[Brady]" denotes a synthetic dolomite sample supplied to us by Dr. Brady.

Our direct electrochemical determination of the Gibbs energy change for the reaction:

2FeOOH(s, Goethite)XFe2O3(s, hematite) + H2O(R)

is nearing completion and will be submitted for publication in the Summer of 1997.

We have in progress an AFM study of the processes of dissolution and reconstruction of calcite and dolomite surfaces. We are studying the effects of Mg2+, SO42- and C2O42-, and other chelating agents on the rates of recession and expansion of surface steps with the objective of quantifying the rates of these processes as a function of solution-ion concentration and composition. Preliminary surface images are particularly interesting (see Figure 1), but much work remains to be done.

 

 

Figure 1. In-situ image of spiral growth structure at a screw dislocation outcrop on cleavage surface of Iceland spar calcite by a contact-mode atomic force microscope (AFM). The image is 12.96 mm wide and data acquisition time was 42 sec. The image was taken using a flow-through fluid cell to which 0.01 M CaCl2-NaHCO3 solution was injected.
